title: Two children in hospital have rotavirus infection
text:
Saturday, 4 February 2017 Two children in hospital have rotavirus infection 
BALING: Six children have been admitted to the Kulim Hospital for suspected rotavirus infection after visiting the hot springs in Ulu Legong near here and two have been confirmed to be infected so far. 
Kedah health director Datuk Dr Norhizan Ismail said the six, aged from two to 11 years old, were from two families who had visited the hot springs between 1am and 4am on Monday. 
He said they were admitted to the hospital between Wednesday and yesterday. 
“The stool tests for rotavirus were positive for two children, one from each family, while the results for the rest are pending,” he said in a statement last night. 
He said all the children, three boys and three girls, were in stable condition. 
Dr Norhizan said the immediate measures taken by the state health department included alerting all hospitals and clinics in the state to report cases caused by visits to the hot springs from Jan 25 to Feb 3 to the nearest district health office, and informing the infectious disease control units of neighbouring states to be on the alert. 
“The Baling district health office is in the midst of identifying the source of infection at the hot springs and its surrounding area. It will close the hot springs for further investigation,” he added. 
Dr Norhizan said the rotavirus, which infects the stomach and intestines, usually attacks children, especially those aged five and below. 
“The symptoms are diarrhoea, vomiting, fever and abdominal pain. 
“The patient could suffer severe dehydration and die if not treated early,” he said. 
He said, among others, the virus is spread through the stools of those infected.
